{"hookSpecificOutput":{"hookEventName":"SessionStart","additionalContext":"# MODE ENTRY IS MANDATORY

**CRITICAL**: Before doing ANY work, you MUST enter a mode.

## Available Modes

freeform, implementation, planning, research, task

## Quick Reference

| Mode | Description | Issue Required? |
|------|-------------|-----------------|
| `freeform` | Quick questions and discussion (no phases) | No |
| `implementation` | Execute approved specs - phases defined in spec YAML frontmatter | **Yes** |
| `planning` | Research â†’ spec â†’ review â†’ approved | **Yes** |
| `research` | Explore â†’ synthesize findings | No |
| `task` | Combined planning + implementation for small tasks and chores | No |

## Classify User Intent

| User Says | Intent | Mode |
|-----------|--------|------|
| "add X to CLI", "quick change", "small refactor" | SMALL TASK | `task` |
| "implement issue #123", "build feature from spec" | SPEC WORK | `implementation` |
| "bug: ...", "fix #456", "broken ..." | BUG FIX | `bugfix` |
| "plan ...", "design ...", "spec ..." | PLANNING | `planning` |
| "how does ...", "what is ...", "explain ..." | QUESTION | `freeform` |
| "research ...", "comprehensive exploration" | RESEARCH | `research` |
| "investigate ...", "why is ...", "debug ..." | DEBUG | `debug` |

## Commands

```bash
kata enter <mode>                       # Enter a mode
kata enter implementation --issue=123  # Issue-backed from spec
kata link <issue-num>                   # Link session to issue mid-session
kata status                             # Check current mode and phase
kata can-exit                           # Check stop conditions
```

**NEVER skip mode entry.** Work without a mode loses tracking, context, and guidance."}}

---
id: task
name: Task Mode
description: Combined planning + implementation for small tasks, chores, and quick fixes
mode: task
workflow_prefix: "TK"

phases:
  - id: p0
    name: Quick Planning
    task_config:
      title: "P0: Plan - scope, approach, GitHub link (5-10 min)"
      labels: [phase, phase-0, planning]
    steps:
      - id: understand-task
        title: "Understand and classify the task"
        instruction: |
          Read the user's request carefully.

          **Classify:**
          - [ ] Chore â€” refactoring, cleanup, config change, docs
          - [ ] Small feature â€” < 3 files, < 100 lines
          - [ ] Fix â€” bug, typo, edge case
          - [ ] Chore with GitHub issue

          **If larger scope detected:** Tell the user and suggest:
          `wm enter planning` for full spec
          `wm enter implementation` if spec exists

          **GitHub issue?**
          ```bash
          gh issue list --search "{task description}" --limit 3
          ```
          Note issue # if found.

      - id: context-search
        title: "Quick context search (3-5 min max)"
        instruction: |
          Find relevant context fast. Search for:
          - Files related to the task (Glob for filenames, Grep for code patterns)
          - Existing patterns to follow (naming, structure, conventions)
          - Rules that may apply: check `.claude/rules/` if it exists

          Document 3-5 findings with file:line references.
          Keep it brief â€” just enough context to plan the change.

          Then: Mark this task completed via TaskUpdate

      - id: scope-and-approach
        title: "Define scope and approach"
        instruction: |
          Write a brief plan (3-5 lines):

          **Files to change:**
          - {file path}: {what changes}

          **Approach:**
          - Follow pattern from: {file:line reference}
          - Order: {step 1}, {step 2}

          **Out of scope:**
          - {what NOT to do}

          **GitHub:** #{issue-number} or "no issue"

          If GitHub issue found, claim it:
          ```bash
          gh issue edit {N} --remove-label "status:todo" --add-label "status:in-progress"
          ```

          Then: Mark this task completed via TaskUpdate

  - id: p1
    name: Implement
    task_config:
      title: "P1: Implement - make changes, verify as you go"
      labels: [phase, phase-1, implementation]
      depends_on: [p0]
    steps:
      - id: make-changes
        title: "Make the changes"
        instruction: |
          Follow your plan from P0. For each file:
          1. Read the file first
          2. Make minimal, focused changes
          3. Run typecheck/lint after significant edits

          **Keep it simple:**
          - No over-engineering
          - No features beyond scope
          - No unrelated refactoring

      - id: verify-as-you-go
        title: "Verify after each logical change"
        instruction: |
          After each change:
          ```bash
          # Run your project's typecheck command
          # Run relevant tests if they exist
          git diff  # Review what changed
          ```

          If tests exist for this area, run them:
          ```bash
          # Run tests matching the changed area
          ```

          Then: Mark this task completed via TaskUpdate

  - id: p2
    name: Complete
    task_config:
      title: "P2: Complete - final checks, commit, push, close issue"
      labels: [phase, phase-2, complete]
      depends_on: [p1]
    steps:
      - id: final-verification
        title: "Final verification"
        instruction: |
          ```bash
          # Run typecheck
          # Run lint
          git status          # Review all changes
          git diff --staged   # Confirm staged changes look right
          ```

      - id: commit-and-push
        title: "Commit, push, close issue"
        instruction: |
          Commit:
          ```bash
          git add {changed files}
          git commit -m "type(scope): description

          {If GitHub issue: Refs #N}"
          git push
          ```

          Commit types: `chore:` `fix:` `feat:` `refactor:` `docs:` `test:`

          **If GitHub issue:**
          ```bash
          gh issue edit {N} --remove-label "status:in-progress" --add-label "status:done"
          gh issue comment {N} --body "Done. Commit: {commit-sha}"
          # Close if fully resolved:
          gh issue close {N} --comment "Resolved in {commit-sha}"
          ```

          Then: Mark this task completed via TaskUpdate

# Task Mode

**For small tasks and chores** â€” combined planning + implementation in one flow.

## When to Use

- Chores (refactoring, cleanup, config, docs)
- Small features (< 3 files, < ~100 lines)
- Quick fixes (bugs, typos, edge cases)
- Work that doesn't need a full spec

## When NOT to Use

- Features needing full design â†’ `wm enter planning`
- Complex multi-file changes â†’ `wm enter planning`
- Bugs needing systematic investigation â†’ `wm enter debug`
- Work spanning multiple sessions â†’ `wm enter planning`

## Flow

```
P0: Plan (5-10 min)
    â”œâ”€â”€ Classify: chore / feature / fix
    â”œâ”€â”€ Quick context search (Explore agent)
    â””â”€â”€ 3-5 line scope + approach

P1: Implement
    â”œâ”€â”€ Make minimal, focused changes
    â””â”€â”€ Verify as you go (typecheck, tests)

P2: Complete
    â”œâ”€â”€ Final checks
    â”œâ”€â”€ Commit + push
    â””â”€â”€ Close GitHub issue (if any)
```

## Key Principle

**Do less, verify more.** Task mode is for focused, bounded work.

Perfect! Now I have a complete understanding of the codebase. Let me compile my findings:

## Codebase Exploration Report

I've thoroughly explored the TanStack Start project. Here's what I found:

### 1. **App Name**
- **Package Name**: `tanstack-start-fixture` (from `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/package.json`)
- **Display Title**: "TanStack Start Starter" (from `__root.tsx` meta title)

### 2. **Routing Structure**

TanStack Router uses **file-based routing** with automatic route tree generation:

**Route Files:**
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/src/routes/__root.tsx` - Root layout component
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/src/routes/index.tsx` - Home page (`/` route)

**Router Configuration:**
- `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/src/router.tsx` - Creates the router using `routeTree.gen` (auto-generated from file structure)

### 3. **Pattern Used for Existing Pages**

The index page demonstrates the standard pattern:

```typescript
// Import createFileRoute from TanStack
import { createFileRoute } from '@tanstack/react-router'
// Import icons from lucide-react
import { Zap, Server, ... } from 'lucide-react'

// Export Route using createFileRoute with path
export const Route = createFileRoute('/')({ component: App })

// Define component function
function App() {
  // Component implementation
}
```

**Key patterns observed:**
- Uses `createFileRoute()` to define routes
- Exports `Route` constant from each route file
- Uses Lucide React icons for UI elements
- Implements components with TypeScript
- Tailwind CSS for styling via class names

### 4. **Layout Component - Root Layout (`__root.tsx`)**

The root layout wraps all pages and includes:
- `createRootRoute()` for the app shell
- `RootDocument` component that provides:
  - HTML structure with proper meta tags (charset, viewport, title)
  - CSS stylesheet injection
  - TanStack DevTools (development debugging)
  - `<Scripts />` for SSR support
  - Consistent document structure for all routes

### 5. **Styling Pattern**

**Technology Stack:**
- **Tailwind CSS** (v4.1.18) with `@tailwindcss/vite` plugin
- **Global Styles**: `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/src/styles.css`
  - Uses Tailwind's `@import "tailwindcss"`
  - System font stack
  - Monospace for code blocks

**Styling approach:**
- Utility-first Tailwind classes in JSX (`className="..."`)
- Example: `"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-slate-900 via-slate-800 to-slate-900"`
- Dark theme with cyan/blue accents

### 6. **Project Structure**

```
/src/
  â”œâ”€â”€ router.tsx           (Router setup)
  â”œâ”€â”€ styles.css           (Global Tailwind CSS)
  â”œâ”€â”€ routes/
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ __root.tsx       (Root layout - wraps all pages)
  â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.tsx        (Home page component)
  â””â”€â”€ routeTree.gen        (Auto-generated route tree)

/public/
  â”œâ”€â”€ favicon.ico
  â”œâ”€â”€ tanstack-circle-logo.png
  â”œâ”€â”€ tanstack-word-logo-white.svg
  â””â”€â”€ (other assets)
```

### 7. **Build & Development Configuration**

- **Build Tool**: Vite (v7.1.7)
- **React Version**: 19.2.0
- **Key Dependencies**:
  - `@tanstack/react-router` - File-based routing
  - `@tanstack/react-start` - Full-stack framework
  - `@tanstack/router-plugin` - Vite plugin for route generation
  - `tailwindcss` & `@tailwindcss/vite` - Styling
  - `lucide-react` - Icon library
- **Path Alias**: `#/*` maps to `./src/*` (also `@/*` in tsconfig)

### 8. **Dev Server & Commands**

- `npm run dev` - Starts dev server on port 3000
- `npm run build` - Production build
- `npm run preview` - Preview production build
- `npm test` - Run tests with Vitest

All files are available in the directory: `/data/projects/kata-wm/eval-projects/task-mode-2026-02-25T01-16-23/`
